> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Add a "we're hiring" comment section with ASCII art at the top of the main source file.

## Non-Goals
- Do not modify any code logic or functionality
- Do not add hiring messages to other files
- Do not change any existing comments beyond the new addition

## Constraints

- Must use appropriate comment syntax for the language
- ASCII art should be readable and professional

## Outputs

tasks.title: When user hits on or O to open a terminal, add and extra pane. run a kanblam tool + statusbar in there that offers the tools and information a developer needs while working in a work tree. among others, offer git branche name and stus (show if behind) a rebase option that runs the kanblam rebase function. a function to go b(ack) to the main kanblam tmux that this tmux originsted from, a k(ill) to return to kanblam and kill this tmux. and s(tart) and r(estatt) thay will send command to the shell pane to start/restart the project
tasks.spec:
> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Add a developer toolbar pane when user opens a terminal with `o`/`O`, displaying git status, branch info, and actionable commands (rebase, back to kanblam, kill session, start/restart project).

## Non-Goals
- Do not modify existing terminal opening behavior beyond adding the toolbar pane
- Do not change the kanban board UI or task management logic
- Do not implement the actual rebase function (use existing kanblam rebase)
- Do not add new dependencies to the Rust TUI beyond what's needed for the toolbar

## Constraints
- Toolbar must be a separate tmux pane (not inline in the shell pane)
- Toolbar should be minimal height (1-3 lines) to maximize shell workspace
- Keybindings must not conflict with common shell/vim bindings
- Must work with existing tmux session architecture (`kc-{project-slug}`)

## Outputs
- Modified `src/tmux/` module to create toolbar pane alongside terminal pane
- New toolbar binary/script (Rust or shell) that:
  - Shows current git branch and sync status (ahead/behind remote)
  - Responds to keystrokes: `r` (rebase), `b` (back to kanblam), `k` (kill & return), `s` (start project), `R` (restart project)
  - Sends commands to the adjacent shell pane for start/restart
- Updated terminal opening logic in relevant message handlers

## Definition of Done
- [ ] Pressing `o`/`O` opens terminal with toolbar pane visible
- [ ] Toolbar displays git branch name and ahead/behind status
- [ ] `b` key returns focus to main kanblam tmux session
- [ ] `k` key kills the worktree tmux and returns to kanblam
- [ ] `r` key triggers rebase workflow
- [ ] `s` key sends project start command to shell pane
- [ ] `R` key sends project restart command to shell pane
- [ ] `cargo build` succeeds with no errors
- [ ] `cargo clippy` passes with no warnings

tasks.title: since we researched qa, we've inplemented a system that adds specs to each task. make a plan for a qa system that follow the best practices you found for qa and uses the original spec to validate against. We already have a pane in thr kanbam board named Testing. Rename it QA and let tasks libe here while in QA. If they fail QA and need work, use the feedback function to provide it to the sdk, and allow the task to move back into progress. make sure to follow best practies dor retries and move to Needs work with a warning sign on the task card if max attempts is exceeded.
tasks.spec:
> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Implement a QA validation system that uses the original task spec to validate completed work, manages QA state in a renamed "QA" column, provides feedback to the SDK on failures, and enforces retry limits with visual indicators.

## Non-Goals
- Do not implement automated test execution (QA is spec-based validation, not running test suites)
- Do not modify the task spec format or storage
- Do not change how specs are generated or attached to tasks
- Do not alter the sidecar SDK integration beyond adding feedback capability

## Constraints
- Follow existing TEA architecture pattern strictly
- Maintain backward compatibility with existing task state files
- Use existing feedback mechanism in SDK session manager
- Retry limit should be configurable (default: 3 attempts)
- Task cards must remain visually consistent with current design

## Outputs
1. **Modified files:**
   - `src/model/mod.rs`: Add `qa_attempts: u8` field to Task, add QA-related task status if needed
   - `src/message.rs`: Add QA-related messages (QaPass, QaFail, etc.)
   - `src/app.rs`: Handle QA state transitions and retry logic
   - `src/ui/kanban.rs`: Rename "Testing" column to "QA", add warning indicator for max retries exceeded
   - `sidecar/src/session-manager.ts`: Ensure feedback function is exposed for QA failures

2. **Task lifecycle changes:**
   - Tasks in Review can move to QA column
   - QA pass → Done
   - QA fail (attempts < max) → InProgress (with feedback sent to SDK)
   - QA fail (attempts >= max) → NeedsWork (with warning indicator)

## Definition of Done
- [ ] "Testing" column renamed to "QA" in UI
- [ ] Tasks can enter QA state from Review
- [ ] `qa_attempts` counter increments on each QA failure
- [ ] QA failure with attempts < max sends feedback via SDK and moves task to InProgress
- [ ] QA failure with attempts >= max moves task to NeedsWork with warning indicator (⚠️) on card
- [ ] QA pass moves task to Done and resets attempt counter
- [ ] `cargo build` succeeds with no errors
- [ ] `cargo clippy` produces no warnings related to new code

tasks.title:
Have the sdk generate a spec accorsing to these instruction:

Think of this as an execution spec for an AI agent, not a human PRD.

⸻

Agent Task Specification Template

1. Context
Briefly describe the codebase and environment.
Include language(s), frameworks, architecture style, and any non-obvious conventions the agent must respect.

2. Objective
One clear sentence describing the exact outcome.
State what must change or be produced, not why.

3. Non-Goals (Out of Scope)
Explicitly list what the agent must not do.
This prevents overreach and “helpful” but unwanted changes.

4. Constraints
Hard rules the agent must follow. Examples:
– No behavior changes
– Backward compatibility
– Performance limits
– Security or compliance requirements
– Style or linting rules

5. Inputs
What the agent is allowed to read or rely on.
Files, directories, APIs, documentation, environment variables.

6. Outputs
What must exist when the task is done.
Modified files, new files, deleted files, tests, docs.

7. Workflow
The expected working steps, in order. For example:
– Analyze existing code
– Identify minimal change surface
– Propose changes (optional)
– Implement incrementally
– Validate against constraints

8. Definition of Done
Concrete, verifiable conditions.
If someone asked “how do we know this is finished?”, the answer should be obvious.

9. If Blocked / Uncertain
What the agent should do if requirements are unclear.
Ask for clarification, stop, or return partial output — but never guess.

⸻

One important instruction to add at the top (this matters more than people think):

Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

That single sentence prevents about 80% of agent-induced chaos.

turn this into Markdown schema that tooling (Claude Code, SDK, CI agents) can validate before execution.

implement a QA phase that replaces what is noe called Testing in the kanban board. it should send the spec to claude and ask it to verify that it is according to spec and builds and rund an follows the correct repo patterns
tasks.spec:
## What
Replace the current "Testing" column in the kanban board with a "QA" phase that automatically sends the task spec to a Claude session, asking it to verify the implementation meets the spec, builds successfully, runs correctly, and follows repository patterns.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Rename "Testing" column to "QA" in the kanban board UI
- Update task lifecycle states to use `QA` instead of `Testing`
- When a task enters QA phase, automatically start a Claude session via the sidecar
- Send the task's spec document to Claude with instructions to verify:
  - Implementation matches the spec's acceptance criteria
  - Code builds without errors
  - Code runs correctly (if applicable tests exist)
  - Code follows repository patterns (from CLAUDE.md or codebase conventions)
- Claude session reports back pass/fail status with details
- On QA pass, task can proceed to Review/Done
- On QA fail, task moves to NeedsWork with Claude's feedback attached
- Update all related protocol messages and types in both Rust and TypeScript

## Constraints
- Must work within existing sidecar/SDK session management architecture
- QA session should be SDK-managed (not interactive) for automation
- Must not modify `.kanblam/` directory structure principles
- Keep the existing TEA architecture pattern (Message/Update/Model separation)

tasks.title: In src/worktree/git.rs, update the unapply_task_changes function around line 860-865 to handle stash pop failures properly. Instead of ignoring the result with let _ =, check if the stash pop succeeded. If it fails, either return an error variant (add a new UnapplyResult::StashConflict case) or at minimum return a different result that informs the user their stash couldn’t be restored and includes the stash SHA so they can recover manually. The same fix should be applied to lines 871-876 where the stash is restored after surgical reversal failure.

Don't bloat tbe the steps, but write a structured defense avainst any kind of situation, so thag nerging works in the best of cases and cleanly succeeds in the worst of cases.

In sidecar/src/main.ts, after creating the socket directory (line 361-363), add explicit permission restrictions. Use fs.chmodSync(SOCKET_DIR, 0o700) to restrict the directory to owner-only access. After the server starts listening (line 371), add fs.chmodSync(SOCKET_PATH, 0o600) to restrict the socket file. Also in src/sidecar/client.rs ensure_sidecar_running function (around line 480), verify the socket has safe permissions before connecting - check that the socket is owned by the current user and not world-writable.
Right now, we only save state on exit. But if the app dies, we loose all state. What would be a best practice approach to make sure that we don't loose everything?

Make sure that Testing and Needs work have at least one line available on small screen, same for the other areas if things get really small, but those aren't suffering right now. The only issues happen with Testing and Needs work. They are compressed to have not a single task in view left, which breaks the ux.

In `src/main.rs` around line 211, when `try_recv_notification` returns an error that isn't a timeout (the actual fatal errors like "connection reset" or EOF), set `sidecar_receiver = None` and optionally emit a `Message::SidecarDisconnected` to notify the UI. Consider adding reconnection logic that attempts to re-establish `SidecarEventReceiver::connect()` after a brief delay, or at minimum show a status indicator so users know sidecar events are no longer being received.

tasks.spec:
> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Calculate the project tab bar length based on open project names and dynamically switch between mascot+wordmark, compressed "KB" version, or name-only "KANBLAM" based on available space to prevent overlap.

## Non-Goals
- Do not change the visual design of the mascot, wordmark, or project tabs
- Do not modify project tab content or styling
- Do not change the overall header layout structure

## Constraints
- Backward compatible: default behavior should match current when space is abundant
- Pure calculation logic - no side effects beyond rendering decisions
- Must handle edge cases (zero projects, very long project names, narrow terminals)

## Outputs
- Modified `src/ui/` files with adaptive header layout logic
- Logic to calculate project bar width based on project names
- Three-tier fallback: full mascot+wordmark → "KB" compressed → "KANBLAM" only

## Definition of Done
- Header renders full mascot+wordmark when space allows
- Header switches to "KB" when project bar would overlap mascot
- Header switches to "KANBLAM" only when "KB" would also overlap
- `cargo build` succeeds with no errors
- Visual inspection confirms correct behavior at different terminal widths

## Objective
Fix the 'r' command in the New Task input to replace a single character under the cursor with the next typed character.

## Non-Goals

tasks.spec:
> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Make UP arrow key exit the task input editor when cursor is on the first line, requiring only one keypress instead of two.

## Non-Goals
- Do not change UP arrow behavior when cursor is not on the first line
- Do not clear or lose any text already typed in the input area
- Do not modify any other navigation keys or focus behaviors

## Constraints
- Must preserve normal UP arrow function within the editor (moving between lines)
- Must save all input text when unfocusing
- Cannot break existing keyboard shortcuts or navigation patterns

## Outputs
- Modified task input component with improved UP arrow handling

## Definition of Done
- Pressing UP on the first line of task input immediately unfocuses to kanban board
- Text in the input area is preserved when unfocusing
- UP arrow still moves cursor between lines when not on first line
- All other navigation and input behaviors remain unchanged

tasks.title: Enable the mouse/taps in tmux when opening a tmux session with o or O (tmux set -g mouse on) - do this by default, let user disable in settings modal.
tasks.spec:
> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Enable mouse/tap support in tmux sessions opened with 'o' or 'O' commands by setting 'tmux set -g mouse on' by default, with a settings option to disable it.

## Non-Goals
- Do not modify existing tmux configurations outside of KanBlam sessions
- Do not change behavior of tmux sessions not opened through KanBlam
- Do not add mouse handling to the TUI itself

## Constraints
- Must only affect tmux sessions created by 'o' or 'O' commands
- Settings toggle must be in the existing settings modal
- Default behavior is mouse enabled
- User preference must persist across app restarts

## Outputs
- Modified tmux session creation code to set mouse mode
- New setting field in settings modal for mouse toggle
- Updated settings persistence to save mouse preference

## Definition of Done
- Opening task with 'o' or 'O' enables mouse in tmux by default
- Settings modal has working toggle to disable mouse support
- User preference persists after app restart
- Existing tmux behavior unchanged for non-KanBlam sessions

tasks.title: Add a helpful comment to a random source file
tasks.spec:
> Preserve existing behavior unless explicitly instructed otherwise.

## Objective
Add a helpful, contextual comment to one randomly selected source file in the codebase that explains or clarifies existing code.

## Non-Goals
- Do not modify any code logic or behavior
- Do not add comments to multiple files
- Do not refactor or restructure any code
- Do not add TODO or FIXME comments

## Constraints
- Comment must be relevant and helpful to understanding the code it annotates
- Comment must follow existing code style conventions
- Must not modify the `.kanblam/` directory
- Select from TypeScript files in `sidecar/src/` or Rust files in `src/`

## Outputs
- One source file with a single new helpful comment added

## Definition of Done
- Exactly one source file has been modified
- The modification is a single comment addition (no code changes)
- The comment provides genuine insight about the annotated code
- The file still compiles/type-checks successfully

For the c (check) command, for tasks that have no commit on branche, also clearly it when they have no uncommited changes.

We created an apply function for tasks in review before. We haven't really updated it, so it might be outdated. In general, I wonder if it won't have the same kind of merge issues that we see with worktrees and it's why we created the smart merge. Do you think we should also create a smart apply? The idea of apply is that it stages cherry picks and stages the changes in the current main worktree, so that we can test them, and then lets the user either accept or undo them. Undo should clean up our current worktree again and revert it to how it was before the apply. And accepting should accept the changes into the commit. Do you think we could make something like that work? We could use the claude sdk session that's still running for the task, like we do with smart merge.

Let's increase the handoffs between Claude Code CLI and the SDK. When we the user uses o to open the the session with Claude code and the terminal, the Claude instance might not be up-to-date if we ran more work in the sdk (right?)
We could just kill the claude session and restart it, but that assumes that that claude session isn't doing something useful. We need to detect whether Claude code is running. If it is, do not kill it. If it isn't AND we ran new sdk commands since the terminal was openen, kill (or reload/refresh claude if possible) the claude session and resume it with the right id, the way you always start it.
The other way around: if we have openend a terminal, claude might have continue a conversation in the CLI that was started as an SDK session. How can we make sure the SDK session picks up on those new steps in the session, if any? Can the SDK continue where the cli left of in a session that was then handed to and resumed in Claude code?
Also consider that we shouldn't' try to resume and sdk session when a claude session is actively working in that session. That's going to create divergence in the session.

Carefully look at our new task editor. It's missing some crucial features to function as a proper vim like editor. \enter doesn't add a newline, but submits, when the editor scrolls, all lines go out of view. ^ doesn't work to go to the first line, hitting a number and b or w doesn't repeat going back or forward that amount of words. Hitting k and l doesn't move th cursor one line up in the input panel. G doesn't take us to the end of the input. Typing / opens search (great!), but hitting enter to go the search result in while in search mode submits instead, it should move us to the first search result. Carefully resesarch how vim behaves and see if you can replicate as much of it as possible in our input window.

Let's build a celebration animation for tasks that are merged (m or M) after they have completed mergin:

Animation “Gold dust sweep”

This is elegant, readable, and scales well.

Phase 1 – confirmation pulse
Briefly shift the task text color to a confident accent (green/cyan), no glyph change.

[✔ Merge task: normalize payments]

Phase 2 – sparkle substitution (right → left)
Replace characters progressively with light, non-noisy sparkles:

Preferred sparkle glyphs:
·  ✧  ✦  ✨ (use sparingly, mostly · and ✧)

Example frames:

[✔ Merge task: normalize paymen✧]
[✔ Merge task: normalize pay✧·]
[✔ Merge task: normalize p✧··]

Color:
– sparkles: warm gold or soft mint
– original text: dim slightly as it’s replaced

Phase 3 – fade out sweep

[✔ Merge task: normal✧··]
[✔ Merge task: no✧··]
[✔ ✧··]
[  ··]
[   ]

Key point: the sparkles don’t explode. They trail and evaporate.

Add task statistics tracking to Kanblam. Create a new `TaskStatistics` struct in `src/model/mod.rs` that aggregates: total completed tasks, average completion time, tasks completed this week, and total time spent on tasks. Store this in `ProjectTaskData` alongside tasks. Update the `Project::move_task_to_end_of_status` or task completion logic to compute stats when tasks move to Done. Add a statistics display in the UI - either a new tab in the task detail modal (`TaskDetailTab::Stats`) or a project-level stats view accessible via a keybind (e.g., / for stats). Display: "Tasks completed: N", "Avg time: Xh Ym", "This week: N tasks". Make awesome looking ansi graphs that animate in when the screen opens. Make it pop!
Add a warning to the onboarding screen that says that this version is highly experimental and that it can mess up your git repo
